items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:            Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction; and
                                    Vida L. Branner, Director of Compensation and Classified Employee Relations
	 
SUBJECT:                    Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m.
	                                    Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From East Side Union
                                    High School District to California School Employees Association, Chapter 187
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the California School Employees Association for the 2012-2013 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its classified employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 2012-2013 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; and reduction of work year.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board sunshine and accept any comment on the District’s initial proposal to the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187.

Branner, Director of Compensation and Classified Employee Relations

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  11.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Escuela Popular Accelerated Family Learning Center Charter Renewal
	 
Escuela Popular Accelerated Family Learning Center is a K-12 charter school authorized by the East Side Union High School District with approximately 100 grade 9-12 students and 260 grade K-8 students. Escuela Popular targets new immigrant Spanish speaking students and is a dual language immersion school which emphasizes academic instruction in Spanish in the early years progressing to content delivered in English in later years.  The student population as well as the instructional model made it challenging to find similar schools for data comparisons. The Charter Renewal application from Escuela Popular Accelerated Family Learning Center has been evaluated to ensure that the Charter School complies with all existing and new California laws and regulations, and it has been assessed on both formative and summative aspects of its educational program.  The financial integrity of the Charter School has also been verified.  Attached for review is the compliance matrix and supporting documents, which demonstrates that the requirements for renewal under Education Code section 47607 have been met.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the renewal of Escuela Popular Accelerated Family Learning Center charter.  The charter will be renewed for 5 years and will expire, June 30, 2017.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.02 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent, Business Services, and Vida Branner, Director of Compensation and Classified Employee Relations
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-27 Cash Incentive Retirement Program (CIRP) for Classified Employees
	 
	 
Pursuant to the Board’s request, an Early Retirement Incentive Program is being presented for consideration for classified (non-management) employees. The program is designed as a one-time cash incentive for eligible classified (non-management) employees.  The requirements for eligibility are similar to those proposed in the certificated supplemental early retirement program (i.e. 15 years or more of continuous service and age 55 or older). There are a total of 114 eligible employees and the program does not require a minimum number of participants.  The incentive program is being proposed as a cash incentive, as opposed to an annuity, because the annuity was not viewed as a viable (cost saving) option for the District. The one-time early retirement cash incentive is designed to provide an eligible classified (non-management) employee with an incentive to retire earlier than they had planned. The classified incentive program is not expected to project any significant savings to the district and is offered as an equitable compromise to the certificated SERP.  The classified one-time incentive program is not projected to result in a loss to the district.  The classified one-time early retirement incentives are as follows: 
Ranges  4-11     $3,000 
Ranges  12-16   $4,000
Ranges  18-24   $5,000
Ranges  26-35   $6,000
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Net Savings Undetermined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund-Benefits
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommend that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2011/2012-27 to Authorize and direct the Associate Superintendent, Human Resources, and Associate Superintendent, Business Services to: 1) Execute the Cash Incentive Program and any and all other documents necessary or proper to implement the Program; 2) Execute any and all documents, including any amendment to the Program, necessary or proper to maintain favorable determination of the Program
items.item_recommendation: It is recommend that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2011/2012-27 to Authorize and direct the Associate Superintendent, Human Resources, and Associate Superintendent, Business Services to: 1) Execute the Cash Incentive Program and any and all other documents necessary or proper to implement the Program; 2) Execute any and all documents, including any amendment to the Program, necessary or proper to maintain favorable determination of the Program

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services, and Presented by Manny Barbara, Silicon Valley Education Foundation
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding the Efforts by the District and its Partners Towards Fulfilling the District Goal Set by the Board in its College and Career Readiness for All Resolution
	 
	 
Background:
Recognizing the challenge to increase the number of students completing the A-G sequence, East Side Union High School District joined other visionary districts in making the A-G sequence the default placement curriculum for all high school students. 
	 
The presentation will provide the Board with an overview of the various initiatives that Silicon Valley Education Foundation and the District have partnered in in order to help increase the number of students completing the A-G sequence.  One of the recent initiatives is a Transcript Audit of the 2011 graduating class that examined the course taking patterns of students towards completing the A-G sequence.  The following are recommendations from the Transcript Audit findings:
Implement Alternative Means for A-G credit recovery
Determine the underlying causes of why students are not accessing the complete A-G course sequence (i.e. student choice or course completion)
Disaggregate data on English Language Learners to determine the root causes contributing to the lack of Access and Success of the A-G sequence
Disaggregate data on special education mainstream students to determine the root causes contributing to the lack of Access and Success of the A-G sequence
Continue articulation with feeder districts
Develop stronger coordinated CTE sequences or pathways, with programmatic standards, that help students develop a set of saleable skills

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion/Action to Approve Final Proposition 39 Facilities Offer and Facilities Use Agreement with ACE Charter School
	 
	 
On November 17, 2011, the Board approved the charter school petition for ACE Charter High School.  On October 28, 2012, Ace submitted a Prop. 39 facilities request to the District to house the Ace charter school and requesting facilities for a projected in-district enrollment of 164.23 students for the 2012-2013 school year.  After reviewing Ace’s request and supporting documentation in December 2011, the District projected that Ace will achieve in-district ADA of approximately 87.36.  Pursuant to Prop. 39 and Education Code section 47614, the District must provide Ace and its in-district students with reasonably equivalent facilities for the operation of its charter high school program.
	 
Administration and Legal Counsel have been in discussions and negotiations with Ace regarding the Prop. 39 facilities request.  Administration recommends that Ace’s charter high school be located in the “D” Villa at the Independence High School site for the 2012-2013 school year.  The subject facilities are located in the southeastern corner of the “D” Villa buildings.  Ace has agreed to accept such offer of space as compliant with District’s obligations under Prop. 39 for the 2012-2013 school year.
	 
The attached draft Facilities Use Agreement identifies the space to be used by Ace and the conditions under which such space may be used, as well as Ace’s and District’s obligations with regard to such facilities.  The term of the Agreement is for one year: July 1, 2012, through June 30, 2011.  The attached draft agreement includes provisions to ensure that use will not interfere with the educational program or activities at the Independence site, will not unduly disrupt the residents in the surrounding neighborhood, and will not jeopardize the safety of the students at the independence site.  Per Education Code section 17529, these standards must be met and findings made by the Board whenever a joint use of an operating school facility is proposed.
	 
Per the Agreement, Ace will pay to the District is pro rata share of costs for the operations and maintenance of the facilities as allowed pursuant to Prop. 39 and the implementing California Code of Regulations.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined; Ace will pay its pro rata share for the operation and maintenance of the facilities in accordance with prop. 39 and Title 5 of the California Code of Regulations section 11969.7.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that: (1) the Board find that the use of the Independence High School facilities by Ace Charter High School on the terms and conditions set forth in the attached facilities Use Agreement will not interfere with the educational program or activities at the Independence site, will not unduly disrupt the residents in the surrounding neighborhood, and will not jeopardize the safety of the students at the independence site, and (2) approve and authorize the execution of the Facilities use Agreement substantially in the form attached hereto for the period July 1, 2012, through June 30, 2013.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion/Action to Approve App Development and Cooperation Agreement
	 
	 
A current District student (minor age) has developed a unique mobile phone app that integrates all of his school site’s website and student functions (e.g., SchoolLoop, site map, etc.) from a single button.  The app is interesting and potentially useful to students and parents throughout the District.  Student, with the consent of his parents, would like to make the app accessible and functional at all of the District’s school sites and at no cost to the District.  The proposed agreement (between District and student’s parents on behalf of the minor student) will allow student to begin work on the app for the other school sites without any cost to the District.  In creating and programming, the app student will not be granted access to confidential information under any circumstance.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration and Legal Counsel recommend that the Board approve the proposed agreement as presented.

Item:  11.07
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading of Proposed Amended Board Bylaw #9270 Conflict of Interest; 
Revolving Door Policy and #9270E (Appendix A) Designated Positions/Disclosure Categories 
	 
	 
Pursuant to the Government Code, the District is required to adopt a conflict of interest code.  The District's conflict of interest code is contained in Board By Law 9270.  The Government Code and the Rules and Regulations adopted by the Fair Political Practices Commission require the District to designate positions which are required to submit disclosures of financial interests, and to update the titles of positions when new positions are created, when position titles are changed, or when positions or position duties are revised or modified to fall within the disclosure categories.  The changes reflected in the attached draft proposed revised Board By Law 9270 and 9270E (Appendix A) clarify that the newly filled positions of Assistant Superintendent, District Architect and Project Manager are included within the category of positions required to submit disclosures.  
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
The Board receive this first reading of the proposed amended Board By Law 9270 and 9270E (Appendix A) thereto as presented.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.09
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant  Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading to Amend Board Policy #6142.7 Physical Education
	 
Description
	 
At the request of the Board, the attached Physical Education Board Policy #6142.7 is an update from existing policy.  The update is presented for first reading allowing for comment during the open period before returning for a second reading and recommended adoption at the May 10, 2012, Board of Trustees Meeting.
	 
This policy was last updated in October 2007.  Changes/additions to the existing board policy are highlighted in red.  The first recommendation is a clarification and second is an addition to current board policy:
Under the section "Two-Year Exemptions" clarifying language has been added for a student who does not satisfactorily meet 5 of the 6 standards of the physical performance test.  The change clarifies the existing ambiguity for when students are unable to pass the state's Fitnessgram.
Under the section "Other Exemptions" language has been recommended to allow a student, grades 11-12, who is engaged in Interscholastic Athletics to be exempt from physical education.  Within the county the practice is mixed with two offering PE Exemptions, three offering credits for athletic participation, two offering a PE class for athletes, and one specific about not offering exemptions for sports:
                     Campbell UHSD - PE Class for Athletes
                     Fremont UHSD - PE Credit through a Sport
                     Los Gatos/Saratoga UHSD - PE Exemption allowed: PE Credit through a Sport
	                         Milpitas USD - No Exemptions For Sports
                     San Jose USD - PE Exemptions allowed; PE Credit through a Sport
                     Santa Clara USD - PE Class for Athletes
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the first reading of the revised Physical Education Policy #6142.7.

SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading of Proposed Amendments to Board Policy 2121 and 
Board Bylaws 9320 and 9321.1
	 
	 
Administration submits the attached proposed changes to Board Policy 2121 (Administration – Superintendent’s Contract) and Board Bylaws 9320 (Meetings and Notices) and 9321.1 (Closed Session Actions and Reports).  The proposed changes are intended to incorporate and address recent legislative changes regarding executive compensation and the new Brown Act requirement that agendas be posted on the district’s website (although that has been the district’s past practice, it was not required by law until very recently).  The new changes in the law are in Government Code section 54956 (requiring posting on the internet and prohibiting special meetings for the purpose of discussing or acting on executive compensation), Government Code section 54243-54243.4 (requiring that certain public agency executives pay back cash settlements in connection with termination if they are subsequently convicted of a crime involving an abuse of his or her office or position) and Government Code 3411.1-3411.2 (regulating the content of automatic renewal provisions in executive contracts).
	 
	 
	 
Fiscal Impact:
None
	 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable
	 
Recommendation:
Administration recommends that the Board accept this First Reading of proposed amendments to Board Policy 2121 and Board Bylaws 9320 and 9321.1.

Board Meeting of April 19, 2012
Item:  11.11
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
Resolution #2011/2012-28
In Support of "My Vote Our Future" Project
	 
	 
WHEREAS, certain vital communities in Santa Clara County, including 18-24 year olds, immigrants, seniors and low-income populations are traditionally underrepresented at the polls; and, 
	 
WHEREAS, traditional voter outreach programs may not be effective in motivating these groups to exercise their right to vote; and, 
	 
WHEREAS, certain community-based organizations that are already serving these communities employ established, individualized methods of communication that are meaningful to these groups; and 
	 
WHEREAS, the Santa Clara County Registrar of Voters is funding a voter outreach and education project entitled My Vote Our Future, which is coordinated by community-based organizations of the nature described above, namely: Catholic Charities of Santa Clara; De Anza College/Parents for Great Education; Services, Immigrant Rights and Education Network/Asian Law Alliance; and Working Partnerships USA; and, 
	 
WHEREAS, in the coming months the My Vote Our Future project, through traditional and nontraditional methods, will focus on increasing voter registration and voter turnout, and work to educate communities on how to complete a ballot, the importance of voting, and new voting rules; 
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, LET IT BE RESOLVED, that the East Side Union High School District endorses and supports the efforts of the My Vote Our Future project. 
	 
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the East Side Union High School District encourages local school districts to develop their own outreach activities, such as holding voter registration drives and special events to deliver the message of how voting could impact local schools; and encourages high school students to coordinate activities to register eligible students and parents; and encourages teachers to conduct appropriate lessons related to voting, so that elementary and middle school students can encourage their parents to engage in the upcoming elections. 
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 19th day of April, 2012, by the Governing Board 
of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.

SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-31 Adopted Admissions Guideline Modifications at San Jose State University
	 
Background
	 
SJSU Ends Admission Guarantee for Local Students 
San José State University adopetd changes to its admissions guidelines beginning 2013/14 that will modify some elements of its existing impaction structure.
	 
Establish campus-level minimum requirements for admission consideration, which continue to provide admission preference to applicants from the local area.
Minimum requirements for consideration of frosh applicants
SJSU will establish a minimum eligibility index above which frosh applicants who do not meet major admission thresholds will be admitted to the university and assigned to the Undeclared major. This threshold will be determined based on the university’s calculated capacity to serve the overall student population, within the principles outlined above.
The campus minimum eligibility index for frosh applicants from the local service area will be lower than the minimum eligibility index required for applicants from outside the local service area, thus providing admission preference to applicants from the local area.
IMPLICATION OF THIS CHANGE: This change replaces SJSU’s long-standing “local area guarantee” at the CSU minimum eligibility level with a “local preference” for admission of applicants from the local service area. It also means that some frosh applicants from the service area who meet CSU minimum eligibility but not the campus-level minimum may be denied admission to SJSU.
Ensure outreach to communities characterized by low socioeconomic status and historically low rates of college going.
SJSU will develop a program known as “Spartan Pathways” to serve a limited number of CSU-eligible frosh and transfer applicants who do not meet major or campus minimum admission thresholds.
Admissions criteria for applicants will include community involvement/leadership, overcoming significant hardship, and potential for degree completion.
Initially, a minimum of 100 enrollment spaces will be allotted to Spartan Pathways, split approximately equally between frosh and transfer applicants. Depending on campus capacity, the number of enrollment spaces filled by applicants to the Spartan Pathways program may be higher.
IMPLICATION OF THIS CHANGE: This program is intended to serve applicants, perhaps from disadvantaged backgrounds, who are likely to have a higher chance of college success than their qualifications would suggest. It provides them with an opportunity for college access based on factors beyond grades and test scores only.
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
	It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2011/2012-31 Adopted Admissions Guideline Modifications at San Jose State University.

SUBJECT:
Receive the First Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering January 1, 2012  through March 31, 2012 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
Background
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CASHEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by the general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from January 1, 2012 through March 31, 2012.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the First Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering January 1, 2012  through March 31, 2012, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

SUBJECT:                    Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From East Side Union
                                    High School District to East Side Teachers Association
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association for the 2012-2013 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 2012-2013 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; reduction of work year, and class size.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board adopt the District’s initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  14.01
Amended
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Bob Bush, SGI Bond Project Manager
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Measure E Unfunded Projects Analysis 
			 
			 
At its public meeting of December 8, 2011, the Board of Trustees for the East Side Union High School District considered the Measure E Forecast & Spending Plan and attendant recommendations from staff.  Given limitations on available Measure E Bond funding going forward, the Board approved moving forward with Phases I & II of Measure E, as planned, and a limited Phase III focused on closing equity distribution gaps. This approach considered a net reduction in scope for the Measure E Bond Program of $79 Million.
			 
At its public meeting of March 8, 2012, the Board was informed of options for disposition of the remaining $79 Million in voter approved authorization by Bond Advisor, Dale Scott & Company. Options presented included deferral of an associated bond sale to some future date (when assessed values that underlie a sale had improved), a capital appreciation bond (that would carry high interest), and returning to voters to make up for the devaluation (a process that would require decertification of the remaining authorization under Measure E).  It is in this context that the Board requested staff to compile a listing of projects that would not be completed if no further funding were made available under Measure E.
			 
Accordingly, staff has conducted an analysis, the findings for which are summarized as follows:
			 
A priority list of projects, reflective of this need, was developed by staff, sites, and cabinet and approved by the Board of Trustees in February, 2009. After the completion of Phases I, II, and the above-referenced limited Phase III of the Measure E Program, approximately $190 Million in projects identified under the Board-Approved priority list (which was subject to availability of funds) would remain unfunded. 
			 
Options are available, subject to the Board’s discretion, to move forward to address a limited set of scope capped at $79 Million or the full scope of $190 Million in remaining “Unfunded Projects”.  If the Board elects to proceed with one of these options, the Board may also wish to consider the merits of proceeding to election in 2012 or 2014. A brief presentation (attached) details potential options and some of the implications that may be considered by the Board.
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Up to 190 Million
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees received the report as presented.

SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action regarding General Obligation Bond Options, Timing of Issuance, and Bond Voter Survey 
			 
At the March 8, 2012 Board Meeting, the Board received an overview of options regarding the issuance of the remaining Measure E General Obligation Bonds.  Based on that presentation, the Board will revisit the options and determine the viability of pursuing a reauthorization or a new GO Bond Election.  In addition, the Board will consider the timing for issuance and whether to direct the District's financial advisor to undertake a random telephone survey of voters to determine their support for re-authorizing the remaining $78 million in Measure E Bonds or providing for a new authorization up to $190 million.  The cost of conducting the bond survey would be paid from the bond proceeds if the Board approves the action and the election is successful. 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Up to $190,000,000
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
GO Bonds
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees discuss, consider and direct the District's financial advisor to pursue either a reauthorization or a new GO Bond election, determine optimal time for issuance, and undertake a random telephone survey of voters to determine support.

SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-32 Authorizing Delivery and Sale of Refunding Certificates of Participation in the Principal Amount of not to Exceed $17,000,000 to Refinance Solar Equipment Lease/Purchase Agreement, and Approving Related Documents and Actions
			 
			 
The District is recommending that it would be in the District’s best financial interests to refinance its obligations under the Solar Equipment Lease/Purchase Agreement dated July 30, 2010, between the Bank of America, N.A., and the District.  The refinancing of the agreement will lower the District’s principal and interest payments due over the next 4 years by $4.2 million dollars.  The proposed short-term savings will provide an added boost to the District’s General Fund during these uncertain budgetary times in the event that the Governor’s proposed tax initiative is unsuccessful.  In the long-term, the district will pay an additional $1.6 million in additional debt service, however, the district believes that the cost are reasonable considering the immediate uncertainty of the State economy and State Budget.  The District’s financial advisor is proposing that the District enter into a Lease and Sublease Agreement with the Public Property Financing Corporation of California, under which the district will lease the Solar Equipment to the Corporation in consideration of the payment by the Corporation of an upfront rental payment to the district which is sufficient to provide funds to refinance the 2010 Equipment Lease.     
 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$4.3 million over 4 years
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund Savings
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-32 Authorizing Delivery and Sale of Refunding Certificates of Participation in the Principal Amount of not to Exceed $17,000,000 to Refinance Solar Equipment Lease/Purchase Agreement, and Approving Related Documents and Actions.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  14.04
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Charles Adams, from Jones Hall, and Cheryl Vesely, from Dale Scott and Company    
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-33 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of Taxable Refunding OPEB Bonds in the Principal Amount of not to exceed $10,000,000 to Refinance a portion of the Debt Service Payments on the 2006 OPEB Bonds, and Approving Related Documents and Actions
			 
			 
The District is recommending that it would be in the District’s best financial interests to authorize the issuance and sale of taxable refunding OPEB (Other Post-Employment Benefit) Bonds in the Principal amount not to exceed $10 million dollars.  This action would allow the District to institute proceedings to refund a portion of the debt service payments coming due on its 2006 OPEB Bonds.  The partial refunding of the OPEB bonds will lower and/or eliminate the District’s principal and interest payments over the next 3 years and provide $6 million in needed cash flow savings.  It is undetermined what the additional debt service will be at this time.  The savings will provide an added boost to the district’s General Fund during these uncertain budgetary times in the event that the Governor’s proposed tax initiative is unsuccessful.  The District is proposing to issue 2012 Taxable Refunding (OPEB Bonds under the refunding bond provisions contained in the California Government Code and under the provisions of the enclosed Indenture of Trust between the District and US Bank as trustee.  Proceeds of the new bond issuance will be deposited with US Bank, as escrow agent, to be deposited into an Escrow Fund from which the payments of debt service on the 2006 OPEB Bonds will be paid when due.  The mechanics for the deposit, investing and applying the proceeds of the new bond issue for that purpose are set forth in the attached Escrow Deposit and Trust Agreement.  
			 
The attached Resolution authorizes the negotiated sale of the 2010 Refunding Bonds to an underwriting firm to be designated by the District, and approves all related financing documents and official actions needed to close the bond issue. 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$6 million over 3 years
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund Savings
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-33 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of Taxable Refunding OPEB Bonds in the Principal Amount of not to exceed $10,000,000 to Refinance a portion of the Debt Service Payments on the 2006 OPEB Bonds, and Approving Related Documents and Actions.

SUBJECT:

Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of March 2012, in response to board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
